Posts.Content: I find the CiPLA brand suits me. I haven't gain weight but loosing it seems even harder than pre Letrozole days.
Posts.Title: Letrozole are dreadful

Posts.Content: I don't think the full impact has really happened for me and I have completed my treatment. Chemo, mastectomy and rads and now on hormone tablets. Like your wife I have appeared strong all the way through my treatment and I am sure it helps. It certainly isn't 'business as usual' throughout treatment ( or after) but feeling positive did help me. With your support your wife will be able to work her way up the mountains she needs to climb. This is a great website with loads of support. She will need some pjs that button down the front for hospital and for duvet days that she is bound to need. Don't feel shy about asking for help, your friends will be more than happy to know they are doing something to help. My favourite help was friends calling in for a drink and natter, hubby always said he loved to hear me laughing when they visited. When your wife feels up to joining us she will find support and answers to her questions from those of us who already have that Brownie badge and others who are at a similar stage in their journey so they can support each other. I know it is really early but do look at booking a place on the Look Good Feel Better sessions ( see discussion post) they are fantastic and the goodie bag is great too. Take care
Posts.Title: Nervous huband

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera. One of my toe nails went ping after 12 months and my fingernails are brittle at the ends. This is probably the last of the chemo nails and the new growth is looking strong and healthy. I used dark polish throughout chemo on fingers and toes and still have them painted - this is my treat to myself! I also have had a couple of bald patches above my ears and thankfully hair is growing back there too! Take care
Posts.Title: 16 months post chemo and still nails coming off

Posts.Content: Here are 7 ways to recycle those no longer needed bras. ¬†In the past I have sent mine to the address in Shropshire. ¬†Can anyone add to this list? http://myzerowaste.com/2010/04/seven-ways-to-recycle-your-bra/
Posts.Title: Recycling - Bras

Posts.Content: Hi DeeDee. I take cocodamol ( and a laxative!) for pain relief. My friend is a distric nurse and she told me to be careful with ibrubrufen (Woops not sure on spelling) as it can cause ulcers and she said to always take it with food. My GP has given me an ibrubrufen gel that I apply directly to the areas of pain. This works well. I try to use my hands as much as possible to stop them seizing up, I find knitting helps to keep my fingers supple. Take care
Posts.Title: letrozole and side effects

Posts.Content: Hi it all sounds normal and it is very early days. Mum will have a follow up appointment with her surgeon soon. If too much fluid builds up and becomes painful it may need draining. Again this is quite normal and being left with as little moob whilst the Seroma drains itself by slowly re plumbing the lymph system. I had my mx in October , tell Mum to do her exercises religiously especially if rads are her next treatment as she will need to be able to raise her arm above her head during the zapping. Soft vests are great. Personally I prefer to wear soft bras and camisoles that hold a falsie rather than a bra as I still find them uncomfortable after a few hours. Hope my ramblings help. Take care
Posts.Title: Post Masectomy - Skin Puckering

Posts.Content: I have had Teva for about 4 months and I have the usual aches and flushes but they are manageable. Next month I have a different brand. Sandoz. I usually collect 2 months worth at a time but asked for 1 month and an IOU in case I don't get on with the new brand. In the last week or so my wrists have become a lot less painful so perhaps my body is getting used to the tablets. - who knows? It will be interesting to see which brands are more 'comfortable' I like the Teva as they come in a calendar pack with days written on.
Posts.Title: letrozole and side effects

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne. Have you ever belonged to a slimming club? Think of it like a bad day of a diet and the leader will tell you to put the day behind you and start afresh in the morning leaving the baggage behind. We all try to be so brave that eventually something has to give and today was that day for you. You may well find that after this little blip your family will understand more about how you feel and may make future discussion easier. I've got all the Brownie badges and still don't think of myself as being ill I'll keep taking the Letrozole and practice the everything's fine face! Do you meet up with other forum members? I can't recommend it enough. Our little group is growing in number and we surprise ourselves with how much we have in common with each other. Chin up tomorrow you will be posting supportive messages for another member. Big hugs
Posts.Title: Very very bad day

Posts.Content: Hi Gill Welcome to the forum nobody want to join. You are at the hardest part - the waiting and the unknown. I started chemo on my birthday and rather than feeling down it felt good to 'get started' I have had chemo, mastectomy and starts rads in a few weeks time. I am now taking Letrozole so am on a similar path to you. Feel free to ask any questions you will get honest and supportive answers from your new friends. The best advice is listen to your body and keep well away from google! And I forgot remember to spoil yourself with little treats ( or big ones) AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: Just Diagnosed.

Posts.Content: Hi. I had a mastectomy last October. It is not a painful procedure so long as you don't over do it when you get home. My scar is very neat, I think my surgeon must have come top of the class in needlework! I didn't have immediate reconstruction and don't think I will have a reconstruction, but, will see how I cope in the summer when wearing less clothing. Take care
Posts.Title: FEELING SO DOWN

Posts.Content: At long last I am off to see some sunshine! ¬†I have adapted 2 of my 'normal' costumes to take my prothesis. ¬†I did buy a special piece of fabric that cost ¬£6.50 then decided I could adapt one of my soft sports type bras. ¬†I have cut the cup part from the bra and sewn it into my costume - fingers crossed it works!!!!! To everyone on the chemo journey - I was at that stage last year - no hair, no holiday, no sun with out slapping factor 50 all over me. ¬†The year does got quickly and soon it will be your turn. Portugal here I come...
Posts.Title: Swimsuit

Posts.Content: I have just bought an Amoema prosthesis from eBay I paid under ¬£40 for. ¬£135 prosthesis (new). If you go on the Amoema website there is a chart where you can use your bra size to work of what size prosthesis you will need. They also offer a sample testing service. They are based in Southampton and I have I friend nearby who has invited next to stay with her and she will take me for a private fitting. Good luck
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Well done! and you've managed to look at your scar! it took me a while to look at mine - hubby was expecting a huge circular cut! ¬†like you I have all my lymph nodes out so scar runs to my armpit - it looks really thin and neat - hope yours will heal as well as mine. ¬†Make the most of being spoilt - don't recover too soon. ¬† My surgeon told hubby no housework for me for 5 years! his face was a picture!!!!! ¬†SHE has a wicked sense of humour.
Posts.Title: had my mastectomy today

Posts.Content: Hi Emma There is very little to worry about pain wise, remain blas√© I had my MX in October and had very little pain. The nurses will probably ask you to rate your pain on a scale of 1-10 and this will determine the pain relief they offer. Remembering to carry the drain around with you is the most frustrating part ( take a bottle shaped gift bag with you to the hospital to make it easier to move about) getting comfortable at night may take a few experiments, there have been previous discussions about heart shaped pillows. Compared to a c section and hysterectomy this operation is no where near as painful.I hope you remain calm and surgery goes well. Treat yourself to some new soft front fastening pjs that will be easy to remove whilst you regain your mobility. Take care AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: One Month Later - Mastectomy photos if anyone would like to see

Posts.Content: Hi Emma. The drain bottle always needs to be below your wound as my hubby reminded me when he found I had placed mine on the bedside table so I didn't need to bend down and pick it up! School girl physics went out the window. I had also been hanging it on my drip stand in hospital and the nurses didn't notice/ realise. This op much wpeasuer than c section and drain much easier to look after than a screaming baby! Alison
Posts.Title: One Month Later - Mastectomy photos if anyone would like to see

Posts.Content: I have just bought an Amoema prosthesis from eBay I paid under ¬£40 for. ¬£135 prosthesis (new). If you go on the Amoema website there is a chart where you can use your bra size to work of what size prosthesis you will need. They also offer a sample testing service. They are based in Southampton and I have I friend nearby who has invited next to stay with her and she will take me for a private fitting. Good luck
Posts.Title: Prosthesis after lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Binny. Whatever it may be you are having all the necessary tests, a poster earlier this morning was told by her GP to wait and see! Don't over think, easier said than done I know but with these tests you will have a very thorough check of your whole body _ this will help you to stop worrying every time you have a twitch or twinge. Will be thinking of you, these scans are very sophisticated, I saw my skeleton projected on the wall, I looked nice and slim! Chin up, don't let your imagination run riot. Bones are classed as very treatable - last May I couldn't get out of bed or dress myself without support, after chemo and Letrozole I am managing to do so much more and this month have returned to my role as Brown Owl!
Posts.Title: Need some help here girls....

Posts.Content: Hi. Hang on in there and keep doing exactly what you are already doing. I remember feeling like I had a hangover without the fun of the previous evening! I couldn't be bothered to read, hubby would offer me the newspaper and I felt my eyes couldn't be bothered to focus - I was due for an eye test but had read to wait until chemo finished, presumably fuzzy eyes go with a fuzzy brain. When you do start to feel better don't start doing too much, use this time to let your body prepare itself for the next session. You next target is to make sure your blood test shows you are fit for treatment no 2. I used to be a very busy person with lots of commitments, since the start of my journey I have looked at what is important and have started to put myself first and what was hardest of all was asking for help. My friends have been fantastic. Keep up the good work. I always felt better once I had taken my last steroid. Hope this helps. If all else fails play candy crush! ( see silly o'clock)
Posts.Title: Headache afterFEC

Posts.Content: Wow Gill that sounds a lovely idea and presumably the drain stays with you I had to remember to pick my bag up every time I moved. Got in quite a pickle when I got up from the swivel chair without the drain! Alison
Posts.Title: One Month Later - Mastectomy photos if anyone would like to see

Posts.Content: Hi Anne. Emend seems to be the Rolls Royce of anti sickness drugs. They come in a pack of three, you take first one an hour before chemo and the others on days two and three. I then went on to domperedone on an as and when needed - my nurse said that sickness was not compulsory and only to use the domperedone if needed rather than take 3 per day. Just a thought - I used to get soooo constipated in first few days and wonder if that could be linked to the headaches? Might be worth trying prune juice, fresh oranges, figs... Then don't go far from a toilet!
Posts.Title: Headache afterFEC

Posts.Content: Hi Ruby It is interesting to see differences in where we are all treated. I had a mastectomy on 19th October, started Letrozole the following week (slight risk of clotting so didn't start before operation). My rads will start on 10th December and if all goes to plan will be finished before the New Year. I am now on week 5 of the Letroxole and am finding my wrists feel stiff first thing in the morning. I am hoping that no more side affects will appear. Good luck with the decision making Alison üéÄ
Posts.Title: Further surgery for 'wider margins' and more lymph nodes to be re

Posts.Content: Emend is brilliant. I ended up with some spare tablets and when I asked about disposing my oncologist told me they were VERY expensive! This may be the reason some people are not given then. However, knowledge is powerful, so go ahead and ask for them. Ideally do this in advance of your next treatment as the first one needs to be taken an hour before chemo. Hope this helps
Posts.Title: Headache afterFEC

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane I felt exactly the same as you have described, in fact my feet and legs were so swollen I had to go out in my slippers as I could not get into any of my shoes. My red blood cell count was low when I had my mx 6 weeks later and I ended up on a course of iron tablets so that might be worth asking about. This is just another step in the process and now 3 months later all I have is the pins and needles in my fingertips and that is getting better every day. I hope you are soon noticing an improvement in these side effects. I'm sure chocolate is a good source of iron? If it isn't it will make you feel good anyway! Or maybe a glass of Guinness? Hope it helps knowing that it is 'normal' to feel like this Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: Is this normal.... Chemo is over but .. 3 wks after and feeling worst...

Posts.Content: Have you tried a variety of different manufacturers? It is the coating ingredients that seem to give the side effects .. I have found a brand of Letrozole that suits me ( CiPLA) in fact I am now worrying that it isn't working as I have very few side effects! You can't win!!!!!
Posts.Title: Anastrozole

Posts.Content: Hi Kath. It is probably the steroids, I remember having to take what seemed like a huge number of tablets with Taxotare doses. Sleep when you can. I remember being wide awake in the night, I downloaded the Daily Mirror app it is free Monday to Friday and is uploaded at about 5 am each day. Candy crush is another popular time waster that I discovered via this forum, some members are on spectacularly high levels in the game. I can assure you that it will get better, so, sleep when you can and try taking the steroids earlier in the day. Take care
Posts.Title: Can't sleep.

Posts.Content: I waited 6 months before using permanent colours and all went well. Good luck it does sound lovely to say " I'm going to the hairdressers!"
Posts.Title: Hair colour

Posts.Content: Hi Alfieval. I had mx with full node clearance. I didn't have any problems pain is minimal and easily controlled with regular painkillers. Within 2 weeks I was driving and took my daughter to Birmingham to watch Disney on Ice. Please don't add extra worry about things that may not happen to you. Plan a few treats for yourself - a spot of retail therapy maybe? Some new pjs that button down the front, soft vest tops or soft bras will all be needed after your operation. Just think after your op the little blighter will no longer be with you ! Stay positive and don't worry about things that may not happen. This is only a short period of your life, albeit a not very nice part. Last year was hard but now I'm planning my summer holiday, I'm back at work part time and I've discovered just how many great friends I have. Take care
Posts.Title: Really scared

Posts.Content: Hi Kelly Wow you manage to keep your wig on for longer than I manage. After a few minutes I used to give up and revert to a soft headscarf or hat. Now I have a full covering of silver ( not grey") short hair I am happy to go out without any covering up. In fact I love having short hair and don't plan to grow it as long as I used to wear it ( shoulder length bob). I can assure you you will not be stared at, in fact my hubby loves my new style. If it's good enough for Jessie J it's good enough for me! Give it a try, you will find it really does help with the temperature control. I finished my chemo 2nd September and only have a few pins and needles in my fingers now, even this is getting better daily although I still struggle with buttons on my blouse. I remember thinking why should the side effect seem to be getting worse now I have finished chemo! Good luck Alison
Posts.Title: Is this normal.... Chemo is over but .. 3 wks after and feeling worst...

Posts.Content: Hi alfieval. After struggling with the excercises given to me buy the physio ( standard ones as per Breast Cancer Care leaflet) I asked for some gentler exercises I could do on on my bed. These are so much easier and I have gained loads more movement in my arm. Remember if you don't ask you don't get! Hope this helps. Take care
Posts.Title: Really scared

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne and welcome to the group none wants to join. You have found the right place for support, up to date knowledge and information, friendship and most importantly a place to let of steam with friends who really do know what you are feeling. The start of the journey is the hardest, it's a bit like riding a bike it's starts with a few wobbles before you quickly learn to peddle up hill. You will get lots of replies from forum members that are at the same stage as you and corn others who have completed treatments. Just a couple of tips always say yes please when help is offered people want to be useful and don't not use Google it is not the place to go searching. Take care sounds like a good excuse to treat yourself you some new pjs! Take care
Posts.Title: Really scared

Posts.Content: Hi Alfieval. Feel free to friend me. I hope I give practical and positive support on this forum. I have had a hysterectomy and Caesarian section and can assure you a mastectomy with full lymph node removal is virtually pain free. Discomfort yes but there are lots of helpful tips on here. Someone suggest a heart shaped pillow to use at night. I have grade 4 with secondaries in my spine and almost all of my lymph nones were affected. If you met me today you wouldn't know there was anything wrong with me. In fact someone told me I look about 46 - not bad considering at 58 I'm only 3 years young than their mother! Keep smiling it can be done and is easier to do with a smile on your face. Do you have Facebook? If so look for Little Daisy Mae. Her father has reported on her daily progress when she was born at 25 weeks weighing less than 2 pounds. It is very humbling to see the weeks of heart ache they went through. Take care and the kettle is always on at my house
Posts.Title: Really scared
Is this normal.... Chemo is over but .. 3 wks after and feeling worst...

Posts.Content: Hi Mudge. Yes chemo is very doable. The D is Taxotare that I took for 3 cycles, it isn't fun and the effects can take a while to work their way through your system. I am assuming the other drug is the C in FEC. To up your survival by 5% with chemo sounds worth the treatment. A bit like dieting " no pain no gain". Good luck with the decision making
Posts.Title: Chemo decision. Yes or no?

Posts.Content: During my radiotherapy session I had an appointment with the lymphoedema specialist. He told me to make a visual check of both arms by holding them in front of me and starting and the wrist compare each arm for difference in size. You would expect your dominant arm to be slightly larger. He then told me I could self refer at any time I became concerned. I would suggest you act sooner rather than later as what you are describing sounds like the checks he told me to carry our before referring myself. Hope this helps. He also gave me a few simple exercises to pump the arm to improve circulation. Take care
Posts.Title: swelling of arm

Posts.Content: Sorry should say I have previously uploaded a copy
Posts.Title: swelling of arm

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie I think you may find a copy of the leaflet I was given by the hospital ( or George if you smile sweetly at him,) Basically whist grasping and ungrasiping your fist raise and lower your arm from your elbow, this works like a pump for the circulation. Hope it helps. Xxx
Posts.Title: swelling of arm

Posts.Content: Hi ¬†Just think - in less than 3 weeks time you will have finished your chemo. ¬†A few tears and tantrums are part of the treatment. ¬†I am sure you will emerge from your bedroom with a smile on your face - we are so go at pretending the the world that all is well. ¬†Either that or you will become the Candy Crush champion if you hibernate for the next few weeks. ¬†Sending you a big hug ¬†xxxxxx
Posts.Title: Can't stop crying

Posts.Content: Yes it is possible BUT very much depends on what you do and how well you cope with the chemo. My consultant told me about a city banker she treated. She has her chemo on a Thursday and took 2 days holiday returning to work the following Monday. She had a wig in same style as her own hair and nobody knew she was having treatment. However, that is probably an extreme example. I managed to work from home for a few hours on 'good' days. I think you need to rest as much as possible during chemo, your body has a big fight ahead of it and you need to work with it by sleeping, resting eating and drinking lots of water. Hope this helps
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and work

Posts.Content: Hi Nanny Mary ¬† So please you have perked up a bit - a full roast cooked for you! ¬†Its amazing what out other halves can do when they put their mind to it! ¬†Mine is a dab hand at the washing - if fact he keeps washing everything in sight!!!! Take care - as my mother in law used to say 'it won't always be dark at 6' - quite apt with the recent clock change
Posts.Title: Can't stop crying

Posts.Content: I live in Stourbridge and have started my journey at Russell Hall Hospital. My consultant is fantastic. I have just finished my 6 rounds of chemo and am due to see her tonight to discuss the next step in my treatment. I have found this forum so supportive and hope that I a, now in a position to offer support to others who are behind me on this journey Take care Alison
Posts.Title: Myocet / Cyclo Chemotherapy Regimen

Posts.Content: My next step is mastectomy in 6/8 weeks time subject to the results of my MRI scan as I have secondaries in my spine. Seeing the oncologist on Tuesday so will know more then. My consultant is lovely, I have every faith in her. Take care Alison
Posts.Title: Myocet / Cyclo Chemotherapy Regimen

Posts.Content: Wow that was super efficient! Now you need to enjoy the New Year celebrations and try and put the appointment at the back of your head for the next week. Whatever you do keep well away from Google, it is not your friend! I know both pieces of advice are hard to follow, but, you have taken the first step now and don't have very long to wait for your appointment. Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: nervous for my tests on Tuesday. trying too keep busy

Posts.Content: Hi Marg. I will be thinks of you tomorrow. With your great sense of humour I'm sure you will make the ward lively. AND when your "young men" come to visit you will have all the nurses fussing around you. Take it easy, make sure you are given your physio exercises before you are discharged. The best bit is you won't need to worry about comfy bras! Love and hugs. Xxxxxx
Posts.Title: op day tomorrow

Posts.Content: I have had a couple of mastectomy related bargains from ebay. I paid ¬£4.99 including postage for a brand new Amoena summer dress with built in shelf bra with fitting for a falsie/s. ¬†I have looked on their web site and the current equivalent dress is around ¬£50. I also manage to find a falsie for swimwear and a new prosthetic boob that is a better fit than the one I was fitted with at the end of last year - that was ¬£35 rather than ¬£135. ¬† The day I went for my fitting I was rather silly really - I didn't realise I needed to take a bra with me - I was still wearing soft vest tops! AND they cancelled the clinic but forgot to phone me so I sat waiting for over an hour before they realised and went to find the BCN who was covering on the ward as they were short staffed. I love ebay! has anyone else had any bargains?
Posts.Title: ebay - bargains

Posts.Content: Perhaps the doctor mention you would be seen within a week, it is supposed to be a rapid response. The speed could be that the unit is quieter over the holiday period. Be thankful you took the phone call my hospital gave hubby my message and I hadn't told him anything! Alison
Posts.Title: nervous for my tests on Tuesday. trying too keep busy

Posts.Content: Hi Katy There is nothing to worry about. The machine is only interested in your chest area and feels like you are in a donut. It's the MRI that encloses you. Thinking of you. Radiotherapy is very manageable the travelling is the tiring part. My hospital gave me a voucher so I only needed to pay ¬£1 parking charge each day.
Posts.Title: CT scan for planning assessment

Posts.Content: Hi Yvonne. You are expecting too much from yourself. It is almost a year since I started my treatment and 4 months since radiotherapy completed my journey ( except for Letrozole and the fun that brings with it). I am still shattered if I do too much. My definition of too much has changed too! I plan rest days where I do as little as possible on other days I plan one commitment only. This is the new me, the old me that dashed from here to there with my finger in lots of pies has gone for ever. What I have learnt is to pace myself, enjoy my friends and rest when I feel tired. Can you knit? I found that really useful as it made me sit down and gave me something to think about. I knitted blankets and cardigans for the charity Preemies UK following an peal by the parents of a very premature baby born locally. She has her own Facebook page. Little Daisy Mae Her dad kept a daily log of her ups and downs it's worth a read it will bring a few tears!!!! And if all else fails there is always Candy Crush!!!!! You are doing so well keep up the good work. Enjoy being a lady of leisure.
Posts.Title: When will I be "ME" again ???

Posts.Content: None of my friends have nominated me! My Mum was 80 last week and I organised a small party for her - she asked her friends to give donations for Cancer Research. I opened a Just a Giving page and with the Gift Aid we raised almost ¬£200. My Brownies held a Fund Raising evening this week and they raised another ¬£200. It's good to see Facebook doing something 'good' so much better than the dreadful neck nominate that took people's lives
Posts.Title: Selfies and donations

Posts.Content: Hi Caroline The mastectomy isn't as bad as you are imagining. I only had 1 drain and I used a bottle gift bag to carry it around in , it might be worth taking one into hospital I had to use a carrier bag I had packed to send dirties home in. Make sure you do your exercises especially if you need radiotherapy as you will need to be able to raise your arm during treatment. Don't let the operation spoil your Christmas! üéÖ Alison
Posts.Title: Chemo tomorrow

Posts.Content: Here is another bargain - summer nightdress with support shelve - brand new - size small http://www.ebay.co.uk/itm/AMOENA-Naomi-Pocketed-Nightdress-Slip-Black-Size-34A-/321397530953?pt=UK_Women_s_Lingerie&hash=item4ad4c92149
Posts.Title: ebay - bargains

Posts.Content: Hi Karen. Where do you swim? It sounds like just the sort of exercise I could cope with. I live in Stourbridge. Hi Flute you have achieved so much in such a short space of time. I suppose it's a bit like you now have time for everything to sink in and the emotions are kicking in. You have certainly been on auto drive for the last year. Time for some 'me time' the kettles always on if you are passing - give me some notice and I will make us some scones with clotted cream. Take care
Posts.Title: I feel so alone

Posts.Content: Thanks Karan It's a bit far to travel for a swim. I will ask around now I know sessions exist. Thanks for responding. It sounds a fun way to exercise and socialise. Take care
Posts.Title: I feel so alone

Posts.Content: Hi Hilary Another of Dr A's patients? I've sent a friend request. It would be good to meet up
Posts.Title: I feel so alone

Posts.Content: Please don't worry yet. If the outcome is not good you might like to friend me. I do have secondaries in my spine BUT I was experiencing back pains that were so bad I could barely get out of bed! Let's hope it is something simple like they have suggested. Take care and try not to self diagnose and keep well away from google. Take care Alison üéÄ
Posts.Title: more waiting. more tests.

Posts.Content: Hi Anne Like you I wasn't told about any foods to avoid, however, I went off yoghurts during my chemo ¬†- it is a standing joke in our hour that pudding - yoghurt! ¬†I think it may be the ones with live bacteria that are to be avoided - its a bit like the list of foods to avoid when pregnant. ¬†I have also seen take aways mentioned in previous discussions. ¬†I had a craving for pate whilst on chemo - I bet that was on the to be avoided list too! ¬†It is so interesting to hear all the different guidance given by staff around the country.
Posts.Title: Yogurt

Posts.Content: Hi Gill I was advised to massage my hand and I did this every time I applied hand cream. By the end of my sessions I needed to use a mild steroid cream as I had some red veins that looked like I was sticking two fingers up! I had my chemo before surgery so had the option to use either hand, but I tried to use my right hand as I am left handed and managed to do this. Hope the next session is easier AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: FEC and sore veins

Posts.Content: Hi jemp. Sorry can't help with natural remedies but hope I can assure you that second FEC will probably be similar to first session, hopefully it. Isn't be better as you will be prepared for the mouth ulcers. I was given Difflam mouth wash this has a mild anaesetic. I was told to use it as a gargle if my throat became sore. I also had Difflam in a spray for sore throats. Hope I have helped to reassure you that round two is doable and you will be armed with the tools to deal with the side effects Take care AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: FEC and sore veins

Posts.Content: Hi Chris You are at the start of your chemo so it is bound to be daunting. Have you been given Emend for days 1-3? I understand that it is a very expensive drug, presumably that is why it is only used at start of each treatment. I think the only advice I can give is listen to your body, sleep whenever you feel the need, eat what you fancy and don't worry if you really don't want to eat much. I had some days when I ate very little, on other days I could have eaten the table leg I was so hungry! This forum is a great place to meet new friends who know exactly what you are going through. I have gained my chemo and mastectomy badges and start work on my radiotherapy badge on Monday. Chin up you can do this, you are probably past the worse part of this cycle. Have a look at previous postings for lots of tips. Have you tried pineapple to help with the vile taste in your mouth? Take care, spoil yourself with little rewards ( or big ones) every step of the way Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: 2 days into chemo.........

Posts.Content: Hi Marg There is no 'normal' during chemo sessions. Listen to your body, rest, sleep or housework! If you run out of housework you can pay me a visit!!!!!! It is probably the steroids that are making you hyper, when they finish you will probably feel like sleeping , I used to nap in the day then be wide awake at silly o'clock. I loaded my ipad with the daily mirror ( free) and often read it at 5am, I have never been so up to date with celebrity gossip! Take care, look after yourself, don't do too much, easier said than done at this time of year. Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: cemo

Posts.Content: Morning Andrea. Someone came with me to each chemo session partly for company and mainly as a second pair of ears and eyes. I had mx after chemo then rads 6 weeks later. I drove myself to these appointments, it was about a 45 minute drive each way plus allowing extra time to find a parking space at busy times! ( early morning appointments are best if you can cope with the early start). In my area we have a charity that will drive you to these appointments so that might be another possibility for you to explore. Rads is by far the easiest part of the journey especially if you can rest after each session. Hope this is helpful
Posts.Title: driving

Posts.Content: I had a great afternoon at this session - it took months of waiting but was well worth the wait - I came out of the room looking 10 years younger! ¬† Each goodie bad is matched to your skin tone and we had 3 beauticians demonstrating and helping us with the 12 steps to making us beautiful. ¬†The how to make eyebrows look realistic was very useful. ¬†Benefit is about to launch a new eyebrow range as they are now one of the new sponsors of this charity - will investigate and report back next month. My daughter has her eye on the perfume! Dorothee watch this space I am going to try and sell it on ebay to boost your sponsorship money for you Moon Walk. Here is the link to find your nearest location: http://www.lookgoodfeelbetter.co.uk/workshops-and-advice/dates-and-locations If you are fortunate to live near several locations you may find a centre with a shorter waiting list. I was fortunate to share this experience with a great friend I have made through this forum - Happy Birthday Gillie B ¬† Would you like to see my before and after pictures?
Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Content: Here are the before and after shots. ¬† For anyone wondering about hair regrowth - I finished my chemo FEC T on 2nd September I lost it very quickly (after 1st FEC) but it did start to grow a few wisps whilst on the Taxotare. ¬†Last onto I had my first trim to tidy up around my ears and back which the hair dresser said was groaning back better than the top. ¬†When I looked at the floor I was expecting to see a few stry hairs, however, she had quite a pile of trimmed hair. ¬†I have gone from mousy blonde to silver grey and now have some curls behind my ears, I have had 'stair rod'' straight hair all my life - who knows a pair of straighteners may be on my birthday list. My daughter has coloured my hair with a 6/8 wash colour (¬£2.59 from Home Bargains) and I am pleased with the results although it doesn't last long as I don't bother with a shower cap so it gets washed every day. I'm going out for a meal tonight so am going to try my new make up skills and get dressed up - hubby will think he has a new woman! ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬† ¬†¬† Your turn next Gille B
Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Content: Thanks Kammy - my daughter commented on how happy I looked. Enjoy the session - unless you want to be 'the model' don't sit at the top of the table! Alison
Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Content: Hi smitten. I am the same age as you. I had a works pension that I have cashed. I now have a lump sum and a monthly payment. Anyone over 55 can cash in a private pension. I might not get as much as I would when reaching retirement age but need the money now and my financial adviser found me a better scheme where my daughter will benefit on my death as well as my hubby. Not a cheery subject but it has been a great help as I can't work as much as I used to before cancer struck. Hope this helps
Posts.Title: returning to work and it isn't the same

Posts.Content: How kind! short of baking you a cake they did you proud! ¬† Hope you are going to use your new skills to make yourself beautiful for tonight's celebratory meal. Enjoy the rest of your Birthday
Posts.Title: Look Good Feeling Better

Posts.Content: This is a hard call. As you are staying in this country I would suggest discussing this with your BCN or oncologist. A holiday may be just what you need as something to look forward to. So long as you listened to your body and rest/ sleep when you need to. The trouble is we all like to be super woman, however I would think if you promised to let your family wait on you hand and foot you would probably cope with the holiday. Until you have started your chemo you won't know how you are going to cope. My surgeon told me about one of her patients who travelled to the West Mids on a Thursday for her chemo, took the Friday as holiday and returned to her high flying post in the City on the Monday and nobody knew she was having chemo! Well I think my rambling is really saying we are all different in how we cope. A holiday as a short term goal sounds good. Presumably if you and hubby didn't go at the last minute everyone else would still go and occupy the cottages? Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: Holidays during chemo.

Posts.Content: It could be the nail varnish - could you try it on a family member to see if they have discolouration after using it? ¬† Alison
Posts.Title: Yellow nails

Posts.Content: Hi Anne The best advice is listen to your body, sleep when it tells you to no matter what time of the day. Please think about your health before your school. I have been a chair of governors for too long so know how hard and dedicated head teachers are. This could be a good development opportunity for your deputy? The other advice is to keep away from Google and paint hand and toe nails black - you will find lots of info re this on previous posts. Your pupils will think you have become a goth! Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: Back to work?

Posts.Content: Hi Kim ¬†I was given Difflam mouth wash and told to gargle with it if my throat felt sore. ¬†You can also buy it as a throat spray - I find it really good an use it as soon as my throat feels dry. ¬† I think it is a case of eating as little and often and accepting the fact that everything is going to fast like cardboard for a while! ¬†Chin up as everyone says this is doable and chemo is be far the worst mountain to climb on this journey! ¬† Not much consolation now but like childbirth you forget the bad bits!!!!! Take care
Posts.Title: First Chemo

Posts.Content: Oh dear this is a viscous circle - the more she worries the less likely it is to lower! ¬†In the scheme of things a week is neither here not there. ¬†Some surgeries loan blood pressure machines - perhaps taking at home when she is relaxing may give a better reading? Big hug for Mum
Posts.Title: MOM - Surgery date

Posts.Content: The scan results this time round are probably for the surgeon - is Mum having a mastectomy? ¬†Her main results will come after the mastectomy. ¬†Don't get too worked up about this operation. ¬†Pain control is fantastic and easily managed - I was given a self administering pump so I was able to give myself a dose whenever I felt I needed it. On a practical level it would be good to make sure Mum has front opening nighties / PJs and for when she comes home. ¬†It is now 5 months since my operation and when I am really tired at the end of the day it is an effort to get clothes off from over my head. Wish I could give Mum a big hug and reassure her she is going to be fine.
Posts.Title: MOM - Surgery date

Posts.Content: Amazon have a selection of books for children to help them deal with cancer in a parent or themselves. Some have the Look Inside facility there is one call something like the hare who lost their hair it is written by a BC survivor who has a three year old when she was diagnosed. There are books to suit early years to teens. I hope this is helpful. I have started it as a new thread so that any suggestions are easy to locate. I hope this is helpful. Alison
Posts.Title: Books to help children understand

Posts.Content: I used dark colours including Prussian blue - my daughter was very impressed with my choices. I found a mobile nail technician who google how to care for nails of cancer patients before she visited me. She also gave me a fantastic pedicure and painted my toenails to match. She suggested I used oil twice a day and gently work into my cuticles ( almond, avocado) . I did not wear open toed sandals all summer to protect my toes. My neighbour lost all his finger and toe nails during his chemo ! Enjoy the'Goth' look. Alison
Posts.Title: Before I ........

Posts.Content: Hi Lou. I asked my oncologist and she told me there is no medical evidence to suggest the need to avoid food high in eostrogen. I try to avoid processed foods, sweets and biscuits but have not totally eliminated them from my diet.
Posts.Title: Er+ breast cancer, dairy or soya ???

Posts.Content: Hi Maria. Welcome to the group no one wanted to join. Everything is very new and raw for you at the moment and this first part is the hardest waiting for your team to sort you individual treatment plan. You will find lots of help, advice, support and up to date knowledge from 'experts' who are further along this bumpy journey. One important piece of advice. - keep away from Google it is not helpful. Someone is always around to respond even at silly o' clock! Take care, let friends and family help in any way they offer don't refuse any offers of help even if you think you can manage. In the last year I have had so many visits from friends that have helped to keep me cheerful and take the strain from hubby for a few hours. He always says it's good to hear you laughing and joking with your visitors. Take care
Posts.Title: first day

Posts.Content: I suppose the holiday periods have made the wait a little longer. Could you phone your GP and ask them to chase your referral and explain your change in symptoms Take care AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: Do docs play down cancer until they get biopsy results or can they...

Posts.Content: Wow Christmas has come early!!!! ¬†Great news - I wish my employer had paid my holiday I accrued. ¬†Im back at work and have to take all my accrued leave before Christmas - sounds good in theory but means I can't keep up with all I need to do!!!!!
Posts.Title: YAY!!

Posts.Content: Hi Anne. You might be interested in my scenario. I have secondaries in my spine and am on Letrozole tablets. My joints ache and I now have a local pain killer cream for this. However after 5 months the side effects are improving slightly. I take Adcal tablets and hate the tutti fruity taste! I also have an injection of demozifab ( think this is the spelling) every 4 weeks to boost bone growth. My oncologist told me this is often given 6 monthly for osteoporosis. This time last year I had very bad back ache and was having physiotherapy, little did I know that this was linked to the lump in my breast. When I started chemo in May I struggled to get out of bed, dress, even get on and off the toilet. As soon as I started chemo my movement improved. The Letrozole tablets are my best hope of keeping the mets contained. So to me a few pains in my joints are a small price to pay. I manage the pain with cocodamol tablets and a laxative to counteract their side effects.... Sounds like the song about the old lady who swallowed a fly!, like me I am sure you will be carefully monitored. Hope this helps.
Posts.Title: Generic Anastrazole - any brand better than another and right old...

Posts.Content: Hi Clare My only child is at university and this morning she set off for her year abroad France this semester and Spain in the next semester. Here university have been very supportive they have said they will pay her fare home when ever she needs to visit me. Her friend was offered similar support last year with train fares to return home each week end. It might be worth him investigating. I finished my 6 rounds of chemo yesterday and see my breast surgeon on Monday to discuss the next steps. This is great site for positive help, support, tips and hugs. I have found many helpful tops and seeing your post made me join as I felt I could add a helpful tip for you. Take one day at a time, spoil yourself with small treats! Alison. üíùüéÄüíñ
Posts.Title: Feeling sad and alone :(

Posts.Content: My daughter is an only child like you. She is also having to deal with her university studies which require her to spend this academic year abroad. Grace has told very few people about my illness this gives her the support she needs without the need to make it common knowledge. Give your mum lots of cuddles, remember it is the small thoughtful acts that can mean the most. This site is a great support for you and your mother, here you will find friends who can give you advice based on their experiences. Is mum having chemotherapy? Perhaps you could paint her nails with a black polish ( see earlier discussions) and maybe do yours as well as a sign of your support. You tube is great for learning how to tie headscarves, use make up to fake eyebrows... As you both make your way along this journey you will both discover who your real friends are. Chin up you and mum will make a great team Alison üéÄ
Posts.Title: Just been told by mum she has breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Kim My surgeon would not do a double mastectomy, at the time I was upset / peeved, however, on reflection I can see why she refused. ¬†I was fortunate that my MX was on my non dominant side, so have not been too reduced in my mobility whilst recovering. I am not triple neg but am at stage 4. ¬†I think you need to take the advice of your team who will offer you the best treatment plan for your body. ¬†it is early days, take one step at a time, there is still lots of time to discuss options. ¬†I'm coping well with my lop sided body and doubt if I will go ahead with reconstruction next year. ¬†This is a journey that needs taking in small fairy steps - it will still get you to the top of the mountain! Take care
Posts.Title: Should I go for a double mascectomy?

Posts.Content: I know what you mean about being a control freak - I'm cringing listening to hubby load the dishwasher wondering what he will chip or smash next! then I realise how ungrateful I am and keep my mouth shut!!! (very difficult)
Posts.Title: Should I go for a double mascectomy?

Posts.Content: Hi Heather Mine is from The Broadway Pharmacy ¬†01384 394856 ¬† However, I think they may be having problems sourcing it - I need to call them in the morning Second 'best' is Teva Alison
Posts.Title: Letrozole side effects

Posts.Content: All the advice you have been given is exactly what I would have responded. Tomorrow I will have gained the full set of T shirts. Chemo 3xFEC 3 xTax followed by mastectomy, Letrozole (I'm post menopausal ) and tomorrow is my 15 th session of radiotherapy. I now have monthly injections to strengthen my spine and the Letrozole to limit any further damage. It is all very doable and with a young family you really do need to,accept all offers of help, if you decline people don't always offer again My friend turned up one Sunday and did all my ironing for me whilst we nattered. Neighbours cooked for hubby whilst I was in hospital and another friend will knock the door and take our dog for a walk. This is a great place to be honest about our feelings and a place where occasionally we are told to pull ourselves together and prepare for battle! Just look at your children and that will give you the strength you need. I dreaded my MRI scan, I visualised my daughter's wedding that I intend being around for whenever she finds Mr Right! ( she's 20 so hopefully not for a few years) Take care Alisonüå∫
Posts.Title: Feeling bewildered

Posts.Content: Thanks for this link. I have been looking for suitable bras as my operation is approaching. I would be delighted to make a donation to McMillan if you would consider posting to me. Alison
Posts.Title: Free to a good home

Posts.Content: I hope Friday goes as well as it can - here are my suggestions: Emend is a great anti sickness tablet - expensive but brilliant - ask if you don't get it prescribed - you need to take the first an hour before chemo Steroids - take the last one no later than 4 pm unless you like being awake all night! Paint your nails black - there are lots of threads in these discussions (fingers and toes) Sleep / rest / listen to your body Ask for mouth wash - I was given Diflam and told it contained a local anaesetic and gargle with it as soon as my throughout felt sore Dont refuse any offers of help - friends may not offer again if you say no first time Pineapple is good for a sore mouth - again lots of links in previous chats Candy Crush - very addictive and good when awake in the middle of the night an ipad or tablet is really useful to while away the hours - the Daily Mirror is free to download on week days and is available form around 5 am No sunshine without factor 50 sunscreen And finally remember you have a great support network here on this site - someone is usually around at any hour f the day or night! Take care
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy

Posts.Content: Hi Chris I have 3 friends who also have this dreaded disease and they are the best people to talk to they know what I am feeling and I can discuss anything with them knowing they understand what I am feeling. Have you been to one of the Looking Good feeling Better sessions? they book up really quickly, I am looking forward to mine in February ( Q E in Brum) and imagine it will give me an opportunity to make more friends. I suppose we have to put ourselves in our family and friend's shoes - what would we feel or say if it were one of them? You have lots of friends here where you can discuss your feelings with people who know exactly how you feel. Take care Alison üíù
Posts.Title: Friday the 13th is upon me - feeling lonely

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca Where would I receive this request? Sorry to sound thick! I have logged in and can't see anything and have not received an email Alison
Posts.Title: Free to a good home

Posts.Content: Hi Kim. I have learnt to bit my tongue every time I hear something break when hubby loads the dishwasher or puts my best socks in the tumble dryer! It's weird being bossed rather than bossing! I do have yo day hubby is really good at reading my face. When he tells me I look pale I know it is time for bed! You never know you might like the fuss and attention. My breakfast was laid out for me today as I copped for an 8.30 appointment for my radiotherapy, not much fun with schools back, it took me twice as long to get there today. Never mind last one tomorrow morning and another early start - I don't get up that early to go to work! Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: Feeling bewildered

Posts.Content: I was told that 8 is the most responsive to hormone treatment, so that is a positive sign.
Posts.Title: Hormone positive receptors..

Posts.Content: Hi I had 3X FEC followed by 3X Taxotare. And like you had a variety of side effects including veins in one of my hands. I had my mastectomy 3 weeks ago and it is not a painful operation - presumably veins in your legs could be used if necessary. You might find it useful to increase the amount of iron rich foods in your diet before your operation, my red blood cell count was a little low and they retested me after my operation with a view to giving me a blood transfusion. 'Luckily' I managed to get away with a month's supply of iron tablets. I am now on Letrozole and will start radiotherapy in a few weeks time. I am hoping that all my sessions will be completed by Christmas. As Highland Mum said you have completed the most challenging part of the treatment already I wish you well as you progress on this beastly journey Alison
Posts.Title: Life after FEC

Posts.Content: Hi You have found the right place for support by joining this forum. You will find some excellent practical advice from 'experts' who are already on this vile journey and others who have completed theirs and are living a new 'normal' life. I wished I has the support from my sister, she fell out with me 17 years ago! A normal healthy diet with lots of fresh fruit and vegetables and avoiding processed foods is a sensible start. Your sister is at the hardest part of the journey - the unknown! Once her treatment plan has been drawn up and she starts her treatment you will both feel relieved that the battle to kill the cancer cells has begun. The best advice that I can give is keep away from google stick to sites such as this one and breast cancer care. Once her treatment has been sorted you will find lots of tips on this forum, it is also a great place for your sister to access when she is feeling low, she will find lots of 'sisters' and a few brothers who will boost her moral. Like your sister my cancer had spread into my lymph nodes. Encourage her to remain positive breast cancer is curable / treatable. Big hugs to you both Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: In shock, supporting my sister, how can I help?

Posts.Content: Hi Karen. I finished my chemo Sept 13 At Christmas I started to you semi permenant hair colours. My hair dresser is now combing through low lights for me and the colour is starting to lift a bit now. I souls suggest asking your hairdresser for their advice. Hope this helps. I have uploaded a picture of my latest cut recently. Take care
Posts.Title: Advice on dying hair 1st time after chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie a while ago I posted a copy of the info sheet / exercises I was given by my hospital's lymphoedema expert. I'm in Portugal at the moment so can't retrieve it for you. I was told to do this exercise regularly throughout the day:- Whilst opening and closing your fist raise and drop your affected arm from the elbow doing this for about 30 seconds each time. I was also told to compare arms side by side as a visual check, your dominant arm should be slightly larger. I hope this is helpful until you get a response from someone who has experienced lymphoedema.
Posts.Title: lymphoedema

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie. No I didn't have any swelling mine was due to poor movement and I have been having physiotherapy and now how much more movement and feeling ion my operation side, it's taken months to get this far but feels great now! Have managed a few swims in the pool too without loosing my falsie!!!!!
Posts.Title: lymphoedema

Posts.Content: Hi Maggie. Part way through radiotherapy I was given a routine appointment withe the lymphoedema nurse where he showed me the exercises and checks I should carry out. From then on I am able to self refer as soon as I have any concerns. I did make an appointment and he took measurements at various points around my arm and assured me I didn't have lymphoedema but did need physio. Keep going with the exercises until your appointment day.
Posts.Title: lymphoedema

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey. I am about to have an MRI and CT scan I already gave secondaries in my spine so this set of tests is to check for any movement. I am no expert but suspect the CT scan looks more at your organs hence the need for a full bladder? Secondaries can be controlled. Feel free to friend me. Take care
Posts.Title: MRI-CT-PET Scans

Posts.Content: I remember the hunger sessions where I could have eaten the table leg! Chemo is hard on our bodies and minds. Like you I had to be on the go every minute of the day and was determined to carry on 'as normal' but this just didn't happen. Don't fight the chemo you need to work with it and if it tells you to have a duvet day don't feel guilty. It sounds like you have a supportive team around you let them help. It is very hard for our nearest and dearest - there is no support for them, no rule book and sometime whatever they try to do for us it is wrong! My hubby has taken the dog out to keep out of my way as he realises tonight he can't do Anything right!! So remember this is only a very short time give chemo the chance to do its job. You will have days where you don't want to eat anything, I always ate what I wanted when I felt hungry and now 6 weeks after all my treatments I weigh the same as when I started this journey back in May last year. Chin up and remember Candy Crush at silly o'clock isn't for ever. Hope you have some plates left!
Posts.Title: So angry

Posts.Content: Hi Judi my mx was in October and rads finished in January. I prefer to wear soft bras and change into soft vests early evening. I do wear a 'proper' bra for best!!!!! But defiantly no wires yet. I'm still tender under my armpit. Saw my lovely lymphoedema / radiographer today and he said the tissue will improved but will always be different. There are some fab soft bras around - I have some that have a pocketed lining that enables me to get my falsie inside ( genie bras from BHS or online). Like hair regrowth it all takes time to get back to something like our 'old self' It's still early days and comfort is important. Take care
Posts.Title: Swelling.

Posts.Content: Hi Marg I feel better today knowing I have a start date and it is a bonus that it will finish before the new year. I am thinking of having a party on N Y Day to say good riddance to 2013. Have you got a soft cotton hat to wear in bed? I can hear my Nana telling me to wear a hat as we loose a lot of heat from our heads! I now have a lot of sympathy for bald men who must get very cold in winter. I started a new hobby a few weeks ago - 'comping' and have just discovered I have won an iPad. Not a bad first win! That really did cheer me up. The team at New Cross who scanned and marked me for my rads were lovely and made sure I was as comfortable as possible. Good luck as you make your way along this hateful journey, but, as you see from so many posts it is all doable and side effects listed are not compulsory. Alison. üéÄ
Posts.Title: hospital

Posts.Content: Hi Emma I had chemo in May, mastectomy and all lymph glands removed in October and have just completed my first week of radiotherapy. I have driven myself to the hospital every day (45 mins) I have negotiated morning sessions as car parking is a lot easier. The staff are friendly and make the experience as pleasant as possible. I take a short dressing gown rather than struggle with the hospital gowns. I have not had any skin problems ( so far) and have used a cream my daughter bought in France ( Biafine) the radio therapist commented on how well my skin was coping - being fair skinned I did worry I might burn. The travelling is probably the hardest / tiring part especially if you get an early appointment, mine are at 8.45 next week with Christmas Day and Boxing Day off ( I have mores time off when working!) Hope this helps. I also had an appointment to see the physio to discuss how to detect / prevent lymphodaema. I hope your D sessions go well, my feet became swollen and I had to go out in my slippers! Have a good Christmas, hope the taste buds enable you to enjoy your Christmas dinner AlisonüíùüéÖüéÑ
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Advice

Posts.Content: My daughter paid 6 euros for the large tube of Biafine, from the pharmacy in France. I will see how it works out throughout my rads but after week 1 my skin does not look any different to what it was before treatment. I will comment again at the end of my treatment for anyone who may be interested. My hubby is inCornwall with my Mother, he has told her about me and explained why we didn't tell her sooner. After the initial shock she understood my reasoning. What a relief now I no longer have to be careful what I say to her on my daily phone calls. Think of me at my 8.45 am appointments this week, I'm dropping my daughter at the supermarket to do our Christmas food shop whilst I have my treatment. Hope I don't go home without her! Have a good and relaxing Christmas Alison
Posts.Title: Radiotherapy Advice

Posts.Content: I used to sleep on my side but have to sleep on my back now. I use pillows either side of me at hip level to stop me rolling over in my sleep. I have been doing this for almost a year now and have trained myself to remain on my back all night. I'm down to one pillow now. The fan we use in the summer time is already in use to help with the overheating during the night. How are you getting on Marg? Bet it's good to be home?
Posts.Title: Getting better but can't sleep at night

Posts.Content: We are a funny lot! I too am in at zzz because my radiotherapy is being delayed because the CT scanner was fully booked until the end of the week. Sooooo on Monday hubby took the whole morning off work, we travelled to a new hospital after a long wait I had a short chat with the consultant, corrected her as to which side was to be treated, I then signed the consent and left! What a waste of time I could have done that at my last appointment with the oncologist. Like you I threw my dummy out of the pram! Chemo is doable so long as you lists to your body and say yeas please whenever somebody offers help ( even if you can do it yourself). After a good nights sleep I am sure you will be back on track Big hugs go you Alison
Posts.Title: hospital

Posts.Content: Hi Marg Glad the new day brought common sense. It did to me too. I have now had my scan and tattoos ready to start my rads on 10th December. I won't be finished before Christmas but should be completed before the year ends. Where are you having your treatment! There is so much positive support on this forum, you came to the right place. Alison
Posts.Title: hospital

Posts.Content: Hi Tracey. My GP has given me Phoroain gel it is ibuprofen for areas that ache, for me that is my wrists. Hope this helps you. When I mentioned it to my oncologist she just put it in her notes without suggesting anything to relieve the pain. Take care
Posts.Title: Appt with ONC Thursday

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca. Your lymph nodes work like filters and hopefully they have stopped the nasty critters getting any further. I had all my lymph nodes removed during my mastectomy. Chin up you are doing so well. Tax is probably a little harder than FEC but you will probably find your hair will start to 'sprout'. So in answer to your question yes people do have a good prognosis. Don't panic take this one step at a time.
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer has spread to nodes, panicking

Posts.Content: Hi littlegem Like you I am almost at the end of my treatment programme. I can hear my phone starting to ping who pith messages for NY already. I am being a party pooper and going to watch MamaMia (again) in bed. If I am still awake by the end of the film I will retire for the night, don't think I can face Garry Barlow wishing me a happy NY. Hope you continue to use this forum, I have learnt and been inspired by many of the regular contributors. Take care Alisonüíù
Posts.Title: Bah humbug

Posts.Content: There won't be much hair to let down! I still have more hurdles, the cancer has spread to my spine so am taking Letrozole and will need regular blood tests and scans to check the Letrozole is doing its job. But it is time to party and book a holiday! Alison
Posts.Title: hospital

Posts.Content: Hi Lyndsey-Ann In my teens and twenties I had 3 fibernomas removed and often complained of pain in my breasts. This was put down to mastitis. I did find it was linked to weight gain and took this as a sign to get some weight off. I wasn't overweight but going a little over seemed to trigger the mastitis. I have heard from a friend ( a gynao surgeon) that his wife was advised to wear a Wonderbra to 'cure' her mastitis. This advice was from my breast surgeon who I have great faith in. So... Whist you are waiting for your results why not give it a try! Worrying always makes the pains worse. It's like when a period is late we convince ourselves we must be pregnant. Take care Alison
Posts.Title: Breast thickening and further tests

Posts.Content: Hi Suzy I am sure this 'news' was a big shock, however, your treatment was planned around your body's needs. Just a quick thought - do you have any insurance policies where you have filled in a family health questionnaire? If so you might need to notify the insurer of this disclosure. Take care Alison üéÄ
Posts.Title: Help! New family info has me scared

Posts.Content: Hi Toni Have you tried using black bail varnish? There have been a few discussions and useful links on this forum recently. I does seem to protect the nails ( fingers and toes). At bit vampy, but if it works it's worth it, my daughter thought I was quite on trend! Take care and hope you are able to complete your treatment Alison üéÄ
Posts.Title: Incomplete chemo treatment

Posts.Content: Hi M65. The only time I had side effects like that was when I has give iron tablets. Black stools is often a sign of too much iron. If the pharmacist suggested contacting your oncologist it might be an idea to go straight to the top! Chemo is unpleasant enough without these added worries. Take care
Posts.Title: FEC - sorry...question about piles and black stools!!

Posts.Title: Brittle nails

Posts.Content: Hi Karan. Have you tried nail clippers rather than scissors? Sounds like a good excuse to treat yourself to a pedicure? I have been having pedicures since my diagnosis and all nails are firmly in place. I had my chemo last summer and alway made sure my toes were covered over. My neighbour caught his toe and the nail pinged off during his chemo so I decided on the mantra 'prevention is better than cure'. My finger nails looked like I had dirt under them I think it was probably dead skin, my friend suggested I put nail oil between the nail and finger tip. This worked a treat, in fact I am hoping that my next manicure will mean all my horrid chemo affected nails will be gone. I would suggest letting someone else cut your toe nails as I know my nail technician has had to be very careful with mine so they stay put! Hope this helps.

Posts.Title: Really scared!

Posts.Content: Hi Angela I have just had 6 chemo sessions. The first 3 were with FEC and the worst side effects were the loss of hair and tiredness. In comparison to taxotere, that I have seen described as FEC's 'Ugly Sister', it is manageable. I was able to continue working throughout my chemo ( I was able to work from home and when I felt up to it). I hope my experiences will help you make your decision. Take care Alison
Posts.Title: To chemo or not

Posts.Content: Hi Hope a mastectomy is very doable - it is not a particularly painful operation. So long as you follow doctor's orders and rest when you are tired and do the exercises you are given you will be surprised how quickly you heal. I am now lop sided and coping better than I thought - in fact I can laugh and joke about it. ¬†The other day hubby was getting on my nerves and I told him he was getting on my tits - my 20 year old piped up no he is getting on your tit!!!!!!! There are some very pretty and sensible mastectomy bras, sleep wear and summer tops available and it's amazing how only you will know the difference when you are kitted out with a false! Let us know how you get on¬†

Posts.Title: Did anyone else develop a teensy consultant crush during their treatment...

Posts.Content: Hi Mel. Loosing your hair is such a horrible sign the chemo is working. Personally, I got hubby to shave my hair when I got fed up of finding it on my dinner plate, pillow and stuck in between my fingers when I showered. I think you will be surprised how you look, my hubby said it was very sexy!!!! I spent a lot of money on my wig and wore it about 4 times. It was hot and itchy! Hats and scarves were much easier and topless around the house. A tip I learnt was keep a hat by the front door so you don't shock the postman!!!!!! Wishing you well with your decision making. Take care

Posts.Title: Is it selfish of me to tell my mum if my grandma she can beat it too...

Posts.Content: Jude Take one step at a time, everyone reacts differently. My best advice is to make sure Mum has lots of rest and you both approach this with a positive 'I can do it' attitude. Posts.Title: Is it selfish of me to tell my mum if my grandma she can beat it too...

Posts.Content: I have members form both sides of my family that had breast cancer BUT this does not mean my cancer is genetic, in fact my consultant told me it was highly unlikely as it would have occurred before I reached 40! I'm fast approaching 60 so she suggests that it is not something my daughter needs to be tested for yet but like all women she should check herself regularly. Take one day at a time and give your Mum lots of love and support, it is great to have a daughter that cares AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: Is it selfish of me to tell my mum if my grandma she can beat it too...

Posts.Content: Hi Mo Thinking of you tomorrow. Although it's not a 'Walk in the park' this operation is not painful. ¬†The theatre team will look after you with even extra care. ¬†The anaesthetic ¬†will be fine - one minute you all be chatting to the theatre staff the next 'minute' you will be in the recovery room. ¬†Within hours I was sitting up having a cup of tea and sandwiches. ¬†The nil by mouth was the hardest part! ¬†Bug cyber hugs - you will be fine, let us know how you get on. ¬†Have you got a little bag you can use to carry your drain in? ¬†I used a gift bag meant for a wine bottle. ¬†Others have used over the shoulder bags - saves leaning it behind when you get up to the bathroom!
Posts.Title: Op tomorrow

Posts.Title: Is it selfish of me to tell my mum if my grandma she can beat it too...

Posts.Content: Hi Kiera I wish I could give you a huge cuddle! I am sure you don't look disgusting, beauty comes from within. I have been a member of this forum for the last 6 months and have read many accounts of 'men' running away from our situations. This doesn't make it any easier for you, hopefully in the not too distant future you will look back and think thank goodness I'm not with that ****** any more (use your own adjective). You could talk to your BCN who will be able to direct you to local support groups. You could also find a Looking Good Feeling Better course. I am sure that you will get many replies and tales of similar ******* I had my mastectomy in October and am just about to complete my rads on Wednesday. I have been left with a very saggy boob and for the first time in my life wished I had been less well endowed! just remember there is always someone worse off than you. Hold your head high, you are a survivor and who know what is around the corner... Put the kettle on and have a cuppa, bar of chocolate, or whatever is your favourite comfort food. Then hit the shops a new handbag always make me feel better! Chin up you can deal with this, AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: I can't cope anymore

Posts.Content: Hi Stoksie. Letrozole does an excellent job even though it has it's side effects. I would ask for a scan because you are getting yourself worked up and that automatically makes the pain worse. Unfortunately GPs have budgets! Their diagnosis is a bit woolly. I went to my GP with back pain, the first he told me to take cocodamol and it might be shingles. The second time I returned I was told the base of my spine was out of line and was referred to a physiotherapist. When she saw me she immediately said I had the spine of a 70 year old (I am 57) and gave me exercises that were so painful / impossible to do. On the third visit to the doctor I showed her the puckering around my nipple and was referred to the rapid response unit. Unfortunately for me the cancer had spread to my spine. So what I am saying is go with your gut feeling, ask for a scan and this will put your mind at ease. The aches and pains associated with Letrozole are part and parcel of the treatment , however you have noticed a change in the side effects and I think you have given it long enough. I hope my story hasn't made you feel worse but has given you the support to become more assertive with your GP. Take care
Posts.Title: Bone scan

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club nobody wanted to join! You have found the right place for advice, support and the occasional rant! We are all such good actors and manage to put on a brave face in front of friends and family when underneath we are petrified. I had my mx in October, it is not a particularly painful operation and the nurses will offer you pain relief. In my hospital they asked me to grade the pain from 1-10 and this determined the medication they administered. Have you been out and bought yourself some new pjs? I chose some soft ones that buttoned up the front for easy access. Take a small bag (gift bag for bottle of wine) to put your drain in when you move around. Some people in previous posts have said they have been provided with a bag made by volunteers. The helpline may be able to give you dome guidance to support your daughter's reaction. I sometime feel it must be harder for those closest to us as they don't get much support and have so many emotions to deal with. And in my hubby's case he has had to learn how to use the washing machine! He still struggles with the induction hob and timers on the oven!!! Bless him!

Posts.Content: Hi Russ You didn't mention the black nail varnish! Made me smile when you commented on wigs and scarves. Here are my suggestions to increase your list:- I have not seen anyone mention Udderly Smooth hand cream I was given this by my chemo nurse along with the Difflam mouth wash. The cream is great for dry hands, feet, knees and any other areas that dry out. The cream was developed for cows to prevent their udders from cracking! I would add hand massages to the list ( and pedicures) as this seemed to help calm my hand where the drip was inserted and they are very therapeutic. Holland and Barrett sell natural deodorants as ordinary ones should be avoided after hair loss. My best advice is to say yes please to anyone who offers to help out and most importantly listen to your body, sleep whenever you need to. Alison
Posts.Title: Lists - what do I need???

Posts.Content: I used soft bras or sports bras when I came out of hospital. A front fastening one is much easier to get on and off. Don't rush to buy proper bras, however you will need on before you go for you prosthetic fitting. I still wear my soft bras as they were comfortable during radiotherapy and even afterwards as I am still a little swollen and don't want to wear anything tight. I started a discussion with links for the genie bras I wear they come with a pocket to take a small foam liner Nd I can get my prosthetic breast in there too. Hope this helps. I also found lots of mastectomy bras on amazon - I am quite an unusual size so have to shop around, they are returnable meaning you can try them on at home. Sainsburys also have a good range of soft / sports bras and think it is one of their 25% off promotions at the moment ( also great for pjs). Happy shopping!

Posts.Content: Hi Lindsey. Welcome to the club no one wanted to join. I don't post very often these days. I'm from the class of 2013 so have all the T Shirts!!!!! ¬†I'm sure you will find all the support you need here on this forum but as I was first to see your post I wanted to respond. ¬†Here are some important tips: ¬† if someone offers to help say yes please even if you don't need it yet, if you decline they probably won't offer again! paint you finger and toe nails black ( or other dark colour) this will protect the nail bed - there are lots of threads in this forum history loosing your hair is probably inevitable, I didn't like my wig and wore hats and pretty scarves - again lots of helpful posts. ¬†My hubby told me I looked beautiful without hair so this boosted my confidence. if you go 'topless' around the house keep a scarf or hat by the front door - I forgot once and wondered why the delivery man was staring at my head! finally keep away from Google it is not your friend. ¬† the waiting game at the start of diagnosis is the hardest, once you have a treatment plan you will start to feel in control. ¬† take care and welcome to this really supportive forum ¬† Alison

Posts.Title: Coping with chemo

Posts.Content: My hair dropped out within 2 weeks of my first FEC session. It got to the stage where I couldn't prepare a meal without dishing up hairs! My hubby persuaded me to let him shave it with his clippers and it felt so much better. I have a wig that I find hot to wear. I wear hats and scarves when I go out and have never felt that anyone is staring at me. At home I tend to go bare headed , remembering to leave a hat by the front door for when unexpected callers knock the door. I forgot this once and wondered why the delivery man had a funny expression on his face. I am a Brown Owl and have had to explain my treatment to them. I compared myself to Jessie J and they now think that Brown Owl is cool! My hair seems to be growing back during my last 2 taxotere sessions I feel this may be due to leaving my head uncovered most of the time. You will know when it is the right time for you to face the clippers - we are all different! Think of the time it will save! There is always a positive for every negative Alison

Posts.Content: Hi Sarah The title of your post sums up my response. It is early days and it does take a while to get used to the terminology.
