Posts.Title: Early days

Posts.Content: Hi Emma. I'm in the stage 4 group with mets in my spine. This was diagnosed alongside my breast cancer. I stEted chemo last May followed by mx and rads. I am now on Letrozole, a daily Adcal tablet to boost my calcium levels and every 4 weeks I have an injection of demozifab ( I think that's the right spelling!). I use co codamol to control the pain and take. Daily laxative to counteract the side effects of the pain killers. So long as I take it easy I can manage many activities. I don't bend down, stretch or lift any more than I have to. I know when I have done too much - usually hubby tells me I am looking pale and he makes me go to bed. I now sleep on my back - I used to put pillows either side of me to make sure I couldn't roll over in my sleep. I have a portable 'Back Friend' that I take out with me so the I am comfortable when sitting in 'strange' chairs. Feel free to friend me. Remember this can be controlled just listen to your body. I'm watching BBC2 's lambing programme. Wow it's amazing!
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: Emma. I hope the new medication works, especially if you have to sacrifice your G and T! Are you on tamoxifen / Letrozole? I have an injection every 4 weeks to boost bone growth have you been given this? And Adcal tablets? Mine are tutti fruity flavour and I can't say they are very appealing. Keep your spirits up. Remember there are some wonderful drugs to control the little blighters
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: Hi Sally google should be avoided on this occasion. ¬†I can't offer any advice but will ask Gille B to respond. ¬†Like me she was from the class of 2013 and pops her head I to the forum every now and then. ¬†Gillie has become a good friend through this forum. We sussed from postings that we lived near each other and shared the same oncologist. ¬† chin up, you know chemo works ¬† alison
Posts.Title: Breast Cancer Round 2-Triple Negative

Posts.Content: Hi Marg. It is still very early days so hang on in there. Feeling a bit low could be the effects of the anaesetic - it is a lot for your body to cope with. I'm sure you will feel better when you have seen your consultant tomorrow. Do you have any of your sleeping tablets left? They seems to cheer you up before your operation!!!! It's hard getting comfortable when you first come out of hospital but I promise you it will get better very soon. Chin up you are amazing. Big hugs xxxx
Posts.Title: fed up

Posts.Content: Hi Emma Of course I responded. You have inspired so many along this vile journey. I always read posts but now only reply if I am one of the first to read a post or where I can add value to posts. I haven't had a reconstruction and at the moment I don't think I am going to bother so this excludes me from many of the discussions. Gillie B uses me as her if Alison can do it so can I!!! We have so much in common, live close to each other and both love cakes, chatting and crafts. I visited my friend and her 8 month old grandson today, I looked at him and had a few sad thoughts. if I ever become a grandma I'll never be able to pick the baby up... It won't stop me from giving it lots of love and cuddles and if I am ever fortunate enough ( my daughter prefers dogs!)
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: There are a few more stages to get through there's the Simon Cowell where it stands up without gel and I have reached the Harry Styles ( one direction) look where even more hair stands up on end! I have always wanted curly hair and now I have curls behind my ears. BUT my hairdresser has managed to give me a pixie cut that is easy to maintain. Keep smiling. Thank goodness for G&J!
Posts.Title: And now I've got sideburns!

Posts.Content: This one follows the Harry Styles! ¬†Jessie J shaved her had last March - I use her as my bench mark when looking at my regrowth. ¬†Im still at the Harry Styles stage - especially first thing in the morning!!!!
Posts.Title: And now I've got sideburns!

Posts.Content: Wow Yvonne great news and good to see you so cheerful! This site is fantastic there is always someone there to give a cheery response. Keep taking the tablets!
Posts.Title: A massive thank you to every one xxxx

Posts.Content: Snap! I was told that the scale of 1-8 is level of responsiveness to hormone treatment with 8 being most receptive. I hope this helps and I'm sure a fuller response will follow from other forum users
Posts.Title: ER8. PR8

Posts.Content: Hi Marie. I have tried a few brands and I find Cilpa the best for me. No sweats and very few aches. I've only tried Sandox from your list. Personally I would try each brand month at a time rather than be stuck with 3 months of the same brand. I noticed an improvement within 2 weeks. I now give the chemist lots of notice so they can get the right ones for me. Good luck with th experiment. I'm not sure they will take back or exchange what you have been dispensed. Take care
Posts.Title: Letrozole question..

Posts.Content: Hi Emma. I have been thinking about you and it's good to hear you sounding positive. The injection is demozifab, not sure that is the right spelling, I have hp the injection every 4 weeks. Keep smiling we are on the wobbly path together. Big hugs
Posts.Title: It's Back! And this time it's...

Posts.Content: I hope tomorrow goes well for you - it is up to you whether you take anyone with you - I didn't tell my hubby anything until I was diagnosed, i don't think I could have faced the fussing, but that is me and we are all very different. Alison
Posts.Title: Undiagnosed and waiting………..

Posts.Content: Hi Joanne If you enter silly o clock to the search bar you will come up with suggestions from the class of 2013. Candy Crush came out tops and some forum use rest reached really high levels. In fact it's their faults that I started playing the addictive game. The Daily Mirror can be downloaded for free on week days and is usually available from around 5 am! Let's hope some more suggestions come flying in. Take care
Posts.Title: Sleepless nights

Posts.Content: One step at a time is the best advice. I have had the 6 chemo sessions, lost my hair, bought a wig I hate wearing so has only been worn a few times. I prefer to wear hats and scarves when out and leave my head uncovered at home. It is really liberating! My hubby likes the Jessie J look! I have my mastectomy on Saturday and start let role the following week. Support from friends and family is so helpful, especially the new friends you have here on this forum - they do understand what you are going through. Remember, there is always someone in a far worse position than you. This is not the best journey to be on, but, this treatment going to help us. Thinking of you Alison
Posts.Title: FEC, Taxotere then Letrozole how do you do this?

Posts.Content: Hi I'm 57 so a little older. ¬†From my experience BIG lumps have to be shrunk by chemo before a mastectomy so the fact that this is to be her first procedure is a positive sign. ¬†Samples will have been taken at her first biopsy and they have to be 'grown' in the lane before all the tests results are available. ¬†More will be carried out after the MX. This is the best place I have found for help, support, guidance and a good rant and weep - there is always someone who will come along a give you a boost - we even manage a good laugh at times! I had my second mama gram 18 months before I was diagnosed so don't let your Mum beat herself up about missing her first session. Love to you both
Posts.Title: Feel like we've been left in limbo :(

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca Your updates are so inspiring. Great news ( except the pain) wishing you a speedy recovery from your latest surgery. Alison üíù
Posts.Title: Oophorectomy and port removal

Posts.Content: Hi I have just returned from a visit to my oncologist and asked her about my 'prune fingers' She said it will take time and is caused by the taxotere. In some cases it does not go completely. She told me to be careful with hot water as I might not be able to feel how hot it actually is. I have noticed this with my feet when I have a bath. I have been knitting throughout my chemo and I think this has helped to keep the circulation in my fingertips. Hope this helps, looks like it is another waiting game we have to play! Take care Alison
Posts.Title: Numbness in fingers

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy. I put the post! Glad you found some bargains! Where did you get your micro bead prosthesis? It sounds interesting. I love their Valetta strappy T Shirts they are far more comfy than a bra. Hope others do as well as you did the quality is excellent.
Posts.Title: Brilliant comfy post-surgery sportswear!

Posts.Content: Hi Paul. The waiting at the start of this ride is the hardest part. Hopefully Russ will come along soon to give you some male support. I went for my first appointment on my own as I didn't want to alarm my husband. I was hoping that I had developed another non cancerous lump - I had the first 2 removed when I was 18. However, in my hear I knew this time it was different and suspected the worst. We are all different and have different ways of coping. All I know was my weight losses at Slimming World were so good my best friend asked me what my secret to the weight loss was!!!! Take care and let us know how you get on. Hopefully your mammogram won't be too painful with less to be squeezed!!!!! Take care
Posts.Title: breast cancer in men

Posts.Content: Hi there is at least one male member of this forum - hopefully he will spot your post and respond. Sorry I can't help much more than this it's getting late!
Posts.Title: breast cancer in men

Posts.Content: I have noticed lots of forum members discussing special cushions made by volunteers for their hospital, now someone has made it into a business...¬†
Posts.Title: Special Cushions

Posts.Content: I have been thinking about you and willing you to return to the forum. Here you are back to your chirpy best! With more mobility. Letrozole may cause a few minor side effects BUT it does a fantastic job controlling those little critters! Looking forward to seeing you on the television. Big hugs xxxxxxx
Posts.Title: Sheep and Cancer - now on TV!

Posts.Content: Hi Katie What a lot of questions! I don't suppose Mum will have all the answers yet! ¬†At the start of this journey we don't have the full picture of the actual cancer - tests are carried out after Mum's biopsy. ¬†Like you Mum I decided to have a mastectomy in the hope that I gave myself the best chance and to make sure that I would not need further surgery. ¬†I had a fairly large lump so had chemo first to reduce its size and improved the chances of the surgeon being able to remove the entire mass. ¬†Radiotherapy is like the cleaning up process - mopping up any stray cells that may have been left. My daughter is a little older than you (20) and when I was first diagnosed I kept it from her a she was about to start her exams at the end of her second year at university. ¬†Grace came with me to one of my chemotherapy sessions and the breast care nurse was able t answer her questions. ¬†I loved it when she snuggled up in bed with me and asked the questions she wanted to ask. You will be able to give your Mum so much practical support, Grace helped me to look my best when I went out by doing my makeup and styling my wig. ¬†She can now cook a brilliant Sunday roast AND best of all cleans up afterwards. ¬† I hope this helps, I'm sure much of this is still very new to your Mum and she probably doesn't know all the answers. ¬†If you look at our recent posts you can see that we are a very caring and supportive group that will help you and Mum with many of the practicalities she is going to face in the next few months. ¬† I am sure my daughter would be happy to friend you on Facebook. ¬†Take care, give Mum lots of hugs and support. ¬† Take care
Posts.Title: Mothers breast cancer- can anyone answer my questions?

Posts.Content: Hi. Are you taking hormone inhibitors? These can cause joint pains, however, for your peace of mind I would suggest going back to your GP and ask for bone scan. Another thought - have you been given any physiotherapy exercises? It's so difficult working out what causes these side effects. Sending you a big hug.
Posts.Title: Severe shoulder pain

Posts.Content: Hi. Are you taking hormone inhibitors? These can cause joint pains, however, for your peace of mind I would suggest going back to your GP and ask for bone scan. Another thought - have you been given any physiotherapy exercises? It's so difficult working out what causes these side effects. Sending you a big hug.
Posts.Title: Severe shoulder pain

Posts.Content: Hi Mina. Have you been taking the anti sickness drug Emend for the first 3 days? It is a very expensive anti sickness drug and from previous discussions it seems not everyone is offered this drug. It worked well for me.
Posts.Title: Feeling sick for 6 days post chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Kate I had a single mastectomy with all lymph nodes removed in October. ¬†I was driving after 2 weeks - advice I was given was if not in pain I could drive. ¬†It is not a painful operation, there is some discomfort and the drain is a bit of a nuisance - especially when you forget to pick it up before you move. You will need to be totally spoilt over the Christmas period - no heavy lifting (except a wine glass) Is someone else cooking for you over Christmas? there are several current discussion posts that will give you lots of information. ¬†the main advice is to do your exercises and listen to your body! Hope you and your young sons have a great Christmas - this operation is very doable - BUT remember to milk the sympathy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Alison
Posts.Title: mastectomy on 20th December

Posts.Content: Hi Wendy. I teach in Adult Ed and returned on a phased return 2 months after my radiotherapy. The works doctor was very supportive and listened to me before sending his recommendations he also asked my permission to request. Full set of my medical notes. On my second visit he had my notes in front of him and he explained lots of my procedures and was in no rush, in fact I stopped him from telling me too much information. I have also had a visit from the occupational therapist to review and thing I need such as a light touch keyboard because my fingers are still a bit numb from the chemo. As soon as I started my phased return I went back to full pay. I am very luck as my boss is so supportive and won't let me over do anything and allows me to work from home for done of my hours. Don't rush back it is very tiring and you need to decide if you are working to live or living to work!
Posts.Title: Teachers out there?

Posts.Content: Hi Mudge Welcome to the group no one wanted to join! This is a great source of support from people who do know exactly how you are feeling. It's good to hear that you were detected quickly, this part is the hardest - the waiting to get started Take care Alison
Posts.Title: First post

Posts.Content: Hi Rebecca I hope the sun is shining for you today. ¬†You were the first person to inspire me through this forum and your fantastic blog. ¬†I do hope that your despondency had something to do with the shitty weather we have been experiencing? ¬†How about pouring your self a glass of your favourite tipple and look at your blog?- this will remind you of how inspirational, kind, supportive and generous you are. ¬†We keep getting kicked a little further down the mountain, but with support we brush ourselves down and continue to climb. Chin up you are a fighter, Take care
Posts.Title: Is cancer not enough?!

Posts.Content: Hi Mollydog I too have just started this drug and am hoping it doesn't thin the new hair that is just starting to grow! Alison
Posts.Title: side effects of letrozol

Posts.Content: Hi. I suffer with overheating at night. I have a fan by my bed and have it on the lowest setting all night. This and a glass of iced water with a straw in helps me to return to sleep quickly. I have started to look at the clock and I seem to sleep for a max of 2 hours before waking a again. I have returned to work but only for a few hours a week, my social life has pm roved since I have been off work and I am happy to return to work on reduced hours. I have been able to cash a private pension early ( anyone over 55 can do this) so can afford to slow down a little as I get very tired and have resigned myself to my new life that runs at much slower pace. I was always dashing around with several part time jobs, school governor and Brown Owl. I now have time to smell the roses!
Posts.Title: Back to work next week

Posts.Content: My Mum is 80 next month - I gave her my old iPad at Christmas - My daughter told me I was wasting my time BUT she is using it and enjoying it too. Yes this is a great site for inspiration - Ive learn of new ways to vent my anger! Love to Mum
Posts.Title: Feel like a fraud on this site

Posts.Content: What a great tip! I have cut up an old soft bra to hold my falsie in a swim suit and that worked perfectly. Don't bin any bras they can be recycled to a variety of charities - I have added a list in an old post, I just googled recycle bras and about 7 charities were listed. Waste not want not!
Posts.Title: Don't throw away your old bra's!! Recycle

Posts.Content: Well done Emma. That is the tallest mountain to climb on this journey. I had a beautiful bouquet of flowers for my last chemo - from the hospital not hubby! ( we have health insurance) I am going to my Look Good session tomorrow afternoon and then to see oncologist - she will think I look better! Perhaps I'll do a before and after shot!
Posts.Title: Last chemo tomorrow!

Posts.Content: Hi Ann. You have come to the right place for support, help, rant and even a giggle or two! As everyone has already said you are at the hardest part, the waiting. Once her treatment commences you will feel more in control. Big hugs to you both xxx. P.S. Are you from the Midlands?
Posts.Title: MOM

Posts.Content: Hi Mumofthe year ¬†6 weeks seems to be the magic number of weeks they allow for recovery between each stage in this journey. ¬†Use this time to prepare some meals for the freezer, paint your nails black (lots of great advice on this forum) find a factor 50 sun protection cream, ¬†and you may wish to investigate the cold cap method if you would like to try and save your hair. ¬† There have been lots of discussions over the value of cutting long hair into a short style before starting chemo - that is something I wish I had done! Good luck with the next part of this journey - the forum is great - there is so much support from 'real experts' Take care
Posts.Title: diagnosis to chemo starting...worried

Posts.Content: Hi Vicki. It seems to be the recovery time between all procedures. You sound well prepared. I couldn't see the point in paying for a trip to the hairdresser when it was going to fall out - I have been married to a Yorkshireman for too long!!!!!! My hair started to fall out after the first session, and my scalp itched like mad, my hair ended up in a tangled clump that I couldn't brush out so I got the scissors and chopped it out. Hubby then clipped it all off and it felt so much better. I didn't wear my wig very often - it was too hot in the summer. I have a huge selection of hats and scarves. My favourite was from eBay. As George said yesterday there are lots of people making money out of us and as soon as you google chemo and hat / scarf the prices double!!!! I did buy a half wig to wear under hats and scarves, so that some hair shows. I now have a short hair style and vey much doubt I will grow it long again. Take care. Search some older posts using key words you will find links for hats, scarves, nails....
Posts.Title: diagnosis to chemo starting...worried

Posts.Content: Hi Vicki. I'm not in Yorkshire just married to a Yorkshire man (Wakefield) One thing you will learn during this is patience!!!! I started chemo on my birthday (May ) mastectomy in October and rads December/ January. I worked through chemo and returned on phased return just as full sick pay ended. My sister in Law is a head teacher in South Kirby. Take care, and a chill pill. I am enjoying having time to do all the lovely things I never had time to do when I was working too many hours every week. This week I am decorating eggs for my Easter tree. Last week included 2 lunches and an evening meal with friends. As they say ' take time to smell the roses!' One of my friends has decided to slow down since spending time with me especially during chemo, she says she realised she enjoyed just sitting and talking without dashing around like a lunatic. Hope this garbled message makes sense.
Posts.Title: diagnosis to chemo starting...worried
I've had such a bad day

Posts.Content: Hi Soniraeb ¬†Yes Letrozole is fantastic, it is controlling my cancer that had already spread to my bones. ¬†A year ago when I started my horrendous journey I found it really hard to dress myself, get out of bed etc. ¬†Now I am able to do so much more and have returned to my part time job. ¬†When I am back at work I am able to 'forget' I have cancer and feel like the old me for a few hours! ¬† I had a mastectomy and don't regret my decision - in fact I don't think I will go for a reconstruction when I have my first year appointment with my surgeon. ¬†I have found a comfortable 'falsie' and a range of tops with a built in shelf to take the false - so much more comfortable than an bra. What ever decision you take we are all here to support you Take care
Posts.Title: Pre surgery.

Posts.Content: I am taking Letrozole and have aches, especially in my hands. I am only on my second month so hope the side effects don't get worse the longer I take it. I try to keep my hands busy and they do seem to improve throughout the day. I have started to knit in the evenings and this does seem to help. I keep reminding myself that it is these tablets that are fighting the remaining cancer cells. AlisonüéÄ
Posts.Title: Medication after chemo and radiotherapy

Posts.Content: I started a link Special cushions ( about 14 pages back) there was an article in the Daily Mirror. Someone also found a valentine's day heart cushion in Home Bargains for ¬£1.99. I hope you find something. I put pillows either side of me to prevent me rolling over in my sleep. In a few days you will work out a strategy to suit you. Chin up you are on your way down the mountain now.
Posts.Title: Feeling rough at minute

Posts.Content: Woops lost what I had just written! We are all entitled to bad days, like you I was up very early this morning reading the newspaper on my ipad at 5 am. I gained weight during chemo especially around my middle. Now 12 months on I am ready to get rid of this wright gain and have joined weightwatchers on line. I'm on Letrozole so loosing the pounds may take a bit longer. Gillie B had a great tip to count down your radiotherapy sessions. Fill a large jar with small chocolate bars, one for each session. When you get home after each session eat one! If chocolate doesn't float your boat you could have a long row of wine bottles. Travelling to and from your sessions is the tiring part. Have you stocked up on Simple shower gel? Huge hug hope you update us tomorrow. Can you knit or crochet? It's very therapeutic and stops me from nibbling food.
Posts.Title: I've had such a bad day

Posts.Content: I have had my swelling drained twice. My consultant then suggested I let my body deal with it and not to have it drained unless it became painful. I started wearing my post mastectomy bra that compressed the area and I am sure my boob shaped lump is going down every day. Exercise is also supposed to encourage the body to remove this fluid. Alison
Posts.Title: Bruising after lymph node removal

Posts.Content: Good morning Mandy. I didn't tell my Mum about my diagnosis - she was recovering from a massive heart attack herself and lives 250 miles from me. She knew I had a bad back and thought that was stopping me from travelling. We kept her in the dark for as long as possible. Lots of friends told me I should tell her but I always responded by telling them she couldn't do anything to help and would worry herself so much and probably make herself more ill. You sound like you have a good coping strategy and now you have found a great set of sisters and a few brothers who DO know what you are going through and can support you with tons of practical tips, commiserate with you when you want a rant and celebrate every time you reach a milestone. Where do you live? You might find other members in your locality to meet up with and chat face to face. Take care
Posts.Title: Is how I am feeling normal?

Posts.Content: Hi Marg. Chin up you are doing so well and have made the journey easier for so many of us with your wonderful inventive ways of celebration. I'll never forget your New Year's Eve party! Sending a huge hug and hope it helps you. Much love
Posts.Title: treatment overload

Posts.Content: I've just read this in today's paper. • WOMEN with at least 15 moles on their skin are 35% more likely to be diagnosed with breast cancer than those with none, a US study from Indiana University suggests. I've got lots of moles...
Posts.Title: Moles

Posts.Content: Hi These are symptoms that your Mum is likely to get, IF she does then Unfortunately many foods taste like cardboard! Frozen pineapple has been suggested on previous posts. Diff lam mouth wash is good and might. E given to your Mum by the chemo nurse. I was given a pot of cream called Udderly Smooth and my daughter massaged this into my feet and knees as drying skin is another possible effect. You Mum is fortunate to have such a caring daughter Alison
Posts.Title: Chemotherapy and Metal Taste in Mouth

Posts.Content: Thinking about you today. Sending big hugs from Cornwall xxx
Posts.Title: Freaking out slightly

Posts.Content: I bought an Amoena one from eBay it is lighter and is shaped for the water to run through it. To be honest it is my fav and I wear it with a vest top that takes a falsie as I find wearing bras uncomfortable. Looking forward to hearing how you get on in the pool. I'm off to Portugal next month and am planning a practice run before I go. BUT have to find a cossie I can fit into first!!!!!
Posts.Title: Swimming with prosthesis

Posts.Content: Sorry I can't offer a scientific reply but as a post menopausal ER + I am taking the hormone Letrozole. Oestrogen is present in lots of foods so perhaps this might be the reason.
Posts.Title: Understanding the reason why I might be on tamoxifen when I've had...

Posts.Content: Hi Flower24. I'm from the class of 2013 too. ¬†Firstly my comiserations to you and your daughter and her loss. ¬†please pick up the phone and visit your GP and get this lump checked out ASAP. ¬†hopefully IT will be something other than what you are dreading. ¬†I'll be thinking of you and hoping that you won't have to face another round of treatment. ¬†Take care, a huge ciber hug to help you pluck up the courage to make that call. ¬†I've delayed a trip to the dentist for almost a week knowing I had a very loose tooth, now I've been I feel so much better and it wasn't as bad I thought it would be. ¬†I'm sure you posted on here for us to give you positive encouragement. ¬† XXXX
Posts.Title: I'm Feeling Scared

Posts.Content: I am HR + and on Letrozloe as I am post menopausal. I don't have too many hot flushes and have learnt to manage them. I have a summer weight duvet and have a glass of cold water by my bed to sip if I wake in the night. During the day I wear layers - it helps to cover the missing boob too! I have secondaries and was told this was my best tool to fight the mets. It is just another thing to adapt to in this new routine
Posts.Title: Hormone receptive

Posts.Content: Well done for completing your first session. Silly O'Clock is a problem. My ipad was a saviour. There are many Candy crush fans on here with incredibly high levels of achievement. I also downloaded the Daily Mirror newspaper it is free mo. To Friday and appears at around 5 am. The only other tip is to take the last steroid at around 3/4 pm. Were you given Emend? It is a fantastic anti sickness tablet BUT I understand it is very expensive so may not be offered as standard by all hospitals. Take care and remember to listen to your body
Posts.Title: First Chemo over

Posts.Content: Hi I didn't tell my husband anything in the hope that it was just another lump (I have had three removed in the past) he 'found out' when the hospital phoned for me and told him when my appointment with Professor C was! ¬†As you can imagine he was a total wreck by the time I for home. ¬†We kept the news from our daughter until she had completed her second year exams at uni. ¬†The uni have been so supportive - she is on her year abroad now and they have paid for 3 trips home so she can come home during term to see me. ¬†
Posts.Title: newly diagnosed with DCIS queery invasive

Posts.Content: Hi Marg. Great decision, I have a few aches and pains that can be controlled by pain relief gel. Hot flushes are something I'm sure you can cope with. IF I can do it I'm sure you can too. Go girl!
Posts.Title: hormone treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Jane. Your comments reminded me of the time I was having an argument with my hubby and I told him he was getting on my tits my 20 yr old chipped in saying " no he is getting on your tit!" Bless her!
Posts.Title: Don't forget to laugh

Posts.Content: Hi Mudge. Wow you have really made full use of this forum and are fully prepared to let the battle commence! Have you looked at the posts relating to painting your nails black ( fingers and toes). Basically this is to protect the nail bed from light / chemo. If you font fancy the goth look some people cover the black with a different coloured top coat. I would also suggest you use a nail oil and put this in your cuticles and down between nail and finger tips. I was given some waterproof dressings after my mx would these be helpful when bathing? I hope all goes well for you. Take care,
Posts.Title: starting chemo - tips and advice please?

Posts.Content: You are doing better than me on Candy Crush - I'm only on level 41. ¬†Like you I have ¬†supportive hubby and lots of friend who visit regularly - its good to have a laugh and natter with them. Wish I had thought about vanilla slices - I did have a few apple donuts with fresh cream and when I felt up to it I made fresh scones with clotted cream for my visitors - perhaps that's why I had so many!
Posts.Title: starting chemo - tips and advice please?

Posts.Content: Hi Patricia You have come to the best place for support - I wish I had found this forum as soon as I was diagnosed. ¬†You will find lots of helpful tips, shoulders to cry on and support from others who are further on their journey. A supportive and loving family makes this horrible journey a little easier. ¬†I am a Brown Owl and had to tell my 'girls' (age 7 - 10) they have been very caring and thought Brown Owl is cool having hair like Jessie J! Take care, you have found a new group of friends Alison
Posts.Title: coping with diagnosis
